segments.en: Linked Discourses 22
9. Senior Mendicants
90. With Channa

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū bārāṇasiyaṃ viharanti isipatane migadāye.
segments.en: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā channo sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito avāpuraṇaṃ ādāya vihārena vihāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Channa came out of retreat. Taking a key, he went from dwelling to dwelling, going up to the senior mendicants and saying,

segments.pli: “ovadantu maṃ āyasmanto therā, anusāsantu maṃ āyasmanto therā, karontu me āyasmanto therā dhammiṃ kathaṃ, yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyan”ti.
segments.en: “May the venerable senior mendicants advise me and instruct me! May they give me a Dhamma talk so that I can see the teaching!”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, therā bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ channaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: When he said this, the senior mendicants said to Venerable Channa:
“Reverend Channa, form,
feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness are impermanent.
Form,
feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness are not-self.
All conditions are impermanent.
All things are not-self.”
Then Venerable Channa thought,
“I too think in this way. …

segments.pli: Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe dhammā anattā’ti.
Atha ca pana me sabbasaṅkhārasamathe sabbūpadhipaṭinissagge taṇhākkhaye virāge nirodhe nibbāne cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.
segments.en: And yet my mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided about the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
Anxiety and grasping arise.
And the mind reverts to thinking:
‘So then who exactly is my self?’

segments.pli: Na kho panevaṃ dhammaṃ passato hoti.
segments.en: But that doesn’t happen for someone who sees the teaching.

segments.pli: Ko nu kho me tathā dhammaṃ deseyya yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyan”ti.
segments.en: Who can teach me the Dhamma so that I can see the teaching?”
Then Venerable Channa thought,

segments.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ, pahoti ca me āyasmā ānando tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyaṃ;
segments.en: “The Venerable Ānanda is staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery. He’s praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. He’s quite capable of teaching me the Dhamma so that I can see the teaching.

segments.pli: atthi ca me āyasmante ānande tāvatikā vissaṭṭhi.
segments.en: Since I have so much trust in Venerable Ānanda,
why don’t I go to see him?”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā channo senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kosambī ghositārāmo yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi … pe … ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā channo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Channa set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Kosambi. He went to see Ānanda in Ghosita’s Monastery, exchanged greetings with him, and told him what had happened. Then he said,

segments.pli: “Ekamidāhaṃ, āvuso ānanda, samayaṃ bārāṇasiyaṃ viharāmi isipatane migadāye.
Atha khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito avāpuraṇaṃ ādāya vihārena vihāraṃ upasaṅkamiṃ;
‘ovadantu maṃ āyasmanto therā, anusāsantu maṃ āyasmanto therā, karontu me āyasmanto therā dhammiṃ kathaṃ yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyan’ti.
Evaṃ vutte, maṃ, āvuso, therā bhikkhū etadavocuṃ:
Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe dhammā anattā’ti.
Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe dhammā anattā’ti.
Atha ca pana me sabbasaṅkhārasamathe sabbūpadhipaṭinissagge taṇhākkhaye virāge nirodhe nibbāne cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.
Na kho panevaṃ dhammaṃ passato hoti.
Ko nu kho me tathā dhammaṃ deseyya yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyanti.
‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ, pahoti ca me āyasmā ānando tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyaṃ.
Atthi ca me āyasmante ānande tāvatikā vissaṭṭhi.

segments.en: “May Venerable Ānanda advise me and instruct me! May he give me a Dhamma talk so that I can see the teaching!”

segments.pli: karotu me, āyasmā ānando dhammiṃ kathaṃ yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyan”ti.
“Ettakenapi mayaṃ āyasmato channassa attamanā api nāma taṃ āyasmā channo āvi akāsi khīlaṃ chindi.
segments.en: “I’m already delighted with Venerable Channa. Hopefully you’ve opened yourself up and cut through your emotional barrenness.
Listen well, Channa.
You are capable of understanding the teaching.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmato channassa tāvatakeneva uḷāraṃ pītipāmojjaṃ uppajji:
segments.en: Then right away Channa was filled with lofty rapture and joy,
“It seems I’m capable of understanding the teaching!”

segments.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, āvuso channa, bhagavato sutaṃ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ kaccānagottaṃ bhikkhuṃ ovadantassa—
segments.en: “Reverend Channa, I heard and learned in the presence of the Buddha his advice to the mendicant Kaccānagotta:

segments.pli: dvayanissito khvāyaṃ, kaccāna, loko yebhuyyena atthitañceva natthitañca.
segments.en: ‘Kaccāna, this world mostly relies on the dual notions of existence and non-existence.

segments.pli: Lokasamudayaṃ kho, kaccāna, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato yā loke natthitā, sā na hoti.
segments.en: But when you truly see the origin of the world with right understanding, you won’t have the notion of non-existence regarding the world.

segments.pli: Lokanirodhaṃ kho, kaccāna, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato yā loke atthitā, sā na hoti.
segments.en: And when you truly see the cessation of the world with right understanding, you won’t have the notion of existence regarding the world.
The world is for the most part shackled to attraction, grasping, and insisting.

segments.pli: taṃ cāyaṃ upayupādānaṃ cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayaṃ na upeti na upādiyati nādhiṭṭhāti ‘attā me’ti.
segments.en: But if—when it comes to this attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendency—you don’t get attracted, grasp, and commit to the notion “my self”,

segments.pli: Dukkhameva uppajjamānaṃ uppajjati, dukkhaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ nirujjhatīti na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati.
segments.en: you’ll have no doubt or uncertainty that what arises is just suffering arising, and what ceases is just suffering ceasing.
Your knowledge about this is independent of others.
This is how right view is defined.
“All exists”: this is one extreme.
“All doesn’t exist”: this is the second extreme.

segments.pli: Ete te, kaccāna, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti—
segments.en: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:
“Ignorance is a condition for choices.
Choices are a condition for consciousness. …
That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease. …
That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”’”

segments.pli: “Evametaṃ, āvuso ānanda, hoti yesaṃ āyasmantānaṃ tādisā sabrahmacārayo anukampakā atthakāmā ovādakā anusāsakā.
segments.en: “Reverend Ānanda, this is how it is when you have such venerables as spiritual companions to advise and instruct you out of kindness and compassion.

segments.pli: Idañca pana me āyasmato ānandassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā dhammo abhisamito”ti.
segments.en: And now that I’ve heard this teaching from Venerable Ānanda, I’ve comprehended the teaching.”

sections.title: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near…

suttaplex.blurb: Remorseful after being admonished by the Buddha on his deathbed, Venerable Channa asks for teachings from the mendicants. Unsatisfied, he seeks out Ānanda, who teaches him the address to Kaccāyana (SN 12.15).
